Posts.Content: sueco wrote: I am 1.5 weeks from ending Afiitor (a chemo pill).  Had to go off because of lung issues.  I had bad nausea and lost 18 lb. on it.  I am sitting here depressed as my stomach is no better.  What are your experiences?  Prescription anti-nausea pill does not work.  I fear I will never feel good again. Posts.Title: Nausea after chemo (how long) sueco SPAMgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2010 01:40PM sueco wrote: I have been very lucky.  Was diagnosed in April 2006 with 4 bone mets.  Arimidex put me with NED for two years.  Then Tamoxifen worked and have been NED.  Just had a PET scan today (every 6 months).  During almost four years, I never have had any pain.  I did have radiation for a met at T5 after the Arimidex stopped working.  I am 66 and have stiff muscles but do feel that swimming and working out and walks help.

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2008 11:30PM sueco wrote: I am going in tomorrow for an ultrasound as my liver enzymes, chol. and tricy. have all risen a lot in the 1-1/2 yrs. that I have been on Arimidex.  My PET scan a few weeks ago was fine.  I keep a record weekly of my weight and have for years.  Since I started Arimidex 1-1/2 yrs. ago I have gained 20 lb.  I know 10-15 lb. of that is from the Arimidex.  The rest are that once I gained weight I quit Weight Watchers and just eat more sweets, but not a lot.  My question is how can you lower these numbers if you can't lose the weight if a medicine is causing it.  Prihode, did you gain weight from your meds?  Great that you were able to lose 20 lb.  I work out every week and eat well.  I will start adding lemon to my water.
Posts.Title: Aromasin gramalola Kindergarten

Posts.Content: sueco wrote: I have read many posts that state their bone mets have healed.  I have been NED for most of four years after starting hormone meds.  The mets no longer show up on a PET scan, but my oncologist just says they are sleeping.  She never says they are able to heal themselves.  Does it mean the bone regrows from Zometa and the cancer cell is still there?   I just hope Tamoxifin works a little longer but will find out next week as I just had a PET scan (every 6 months). Posts.Title: Do bone mets heal? sueco ibcmets

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2014 06:07PM sueco wrote: I get a PET scan every six months for eight years.  Never had the contract you mentioned.  I am on Medicare and my doctor said there is no truth to Medicare only allowing two scans in a lifetime if you are being treated for cancer.  I cant recall exactly what she said, but I recall that if you are just getting a PET to see if you have cancer you are only allowed to do this twice in your lifetime.  No limit on scans once you are being treated for cancer.  I do believe though that Medicare only allows two such scans a year, but even then if circumstances call for a third the doctor can try to get that approved.
Posts.Title: Pet scan vs. Pet scan with CT contrast DivineMrsM ibcmets

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2007 05:56PM sueco wrote: I had surgery to remove a tumor a year ago. Because it had spread to two lymph nodes, my oncologist said I needed chemo. Before starting chemo though she wanted a PET scan. The PET scan showed three bone mets. Fortunately Arimidex resolved the mets. I now wonder if my insurance company will pay for a PET scan every six months to see if I have new mets. If I did not have lymph node involvement, I am sure I would have never had a PET scan. As the cells can also travel through blood vessels from the tumor, I would have never known I had bone mets until I had pain in the future.
Posts.Title: ASCO recommends NO tests for BC follow-up betmart mar8dar

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2008 02:29PM sueco wrote: I have checked all my breast cancer favorites, and can't find the article I read about this.  I do remember something like the bones were more of a friendly environment for cancer cells.  Also remember reading that they first grow in the spine and hip areas because they are the closest to the breasts so the cells don't have to travel as far.
Posts.Title: Bone Mets cleomoon HeatherBLocklear

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2015 04:08PM sueco wrote: Have you been on Xeloda yet?  I know it is a chemo, and the first I have been on.  The difference between Afinitor and Xeloda has been unbelievable for me.   I had to go off Afinitor as it was affecting my lungs, I felt so terrible.  One day a man saw me in Home Depot pushing a cart, and he asked if I was okay.  I didn't think I looked that bad.  I have been on Xeloda for over a year.  Now I am older and retired, and yes I need a nap many days but I feel it is my age too.  I have few side effects, and feel I could work if I was not retired.  Only problem I have is needing to be near a restroom as this med has caused diarrhea often but I can live with it.  No stomach issues.  Red feet but no hand problems.  Gee I sound like an advertisement for Xeloda, but I still have such bad feelings towards Afinitor.  The one thing to remember though is that all react differently towards different meds during this journey.  There is an active chat room I think on Afinitor where you may learn more.
Posts.Title: Working full time while taking Afinitor? allyannea Josiesemp

Posts.Content: May 4, 2015 04:13PM sueco wrote: Tough decision.  I assume all my meds show up below my message.  I have had to change meds like every two years as the cancel cells came back to life which is common as they figure out a way to get around the meds.  Some time back I had T8 radiated.  I wish I would have waited because as soon as I started a new hormone med it would have gone to sleep again like the other bone mets in my vertebra did..  I just know so little but I just seem to recall the more radiation you have the less effective a chemo or med will be in the future.  I did have to have C4 and 5 radiated though as I had pain because the met was pressing against a nerve.  I am sure your doctor will help clarify all of this.  I personally have doubts with the every 6 month PET scans I have.  One showed I had a new met in the femur but never again has this appeared in a scan in over four years.  Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Slight progression-add rads only? Please help starbrightlyshines Romansma

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2014 05:44PM sueco wrote: Jen, so happy for you.  I am wondering though what medical treatment you have received in the past six years.  Anti hormone meds, chemo, radiation?  Are you still taking any meds as you continue to be NED?
Posts.Title: PET scan says NED ... 6 years strong JeninMichigan roberta37

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2008 11:57AM sueco wrote: I have had two infusions.  Both times I ran a fever and felt awful for one day and less so the next day.  Third day I felt fine.  I just plan on making sure that my next infusion is on a day where I know I can just lay around for a day or two.  Fortunately I did not feel sick to my stomach.  The first time I asked the nurse if I could have wine later in the day, and she said sure.  I really think that was bad advice.  Really important to drink a lot of water before and especially after the infusion.
Posts.Title: Zometa mthomp2020 freeariesonline

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2008 07:38AM sueco wrote: I did receive a small booklet from the nurse who gave me the Zometa called HOW ZOMETA HELPS DEFEND YOUR INDEPENDENCE.  It has pictures showing how it works.   It states it makes it harder for the cancer cells to stick to the bones, slows bone destruction by shortening the lives of the osteoclasts and making it harder for the osteoclasts to destroy the bone.  As this was put out by Zometa, I assume most doctor's offices should have it.
Posts.Title: Zometa mthomp2020 freeariesonline

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2014 06:40PM sueco wrote: I have been reading this post for months.  I am almost 72.  Doing okay with Xeloda for months and my stomach and diarrhea have gotten better. Any advice about your experience with travel.  I can sit and garden for a long time but last like 20 min. if I am on my legs.  I then need to rest.  I want to take a trip before my PET scan in November.  My son lives in Hawaii but I just fear flying like 9 hours on a plane.  I am also checking into take the train from Seattle to Vancouver and then on to Calgary.  My husband dreads dealing with customs and money exchange.  We fly to Seattle from Denver first.  I booked a seat towards the very back of the plane if I have diarrhea issues.  We would also be on a plane from Calgary to Denver.  I just think of how our breast cancer changes things and how one has to think of all the issues involving our meds and side effects and our stamina.  Any advice?
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2010 11:45PM sueco wrote: Diagnosed with BC along with bone mets April 2006.  Arimidex kept me with NED for two years.  I was then put on Tamoxifen when mets reappeared.  I just had my monthly PET scan and I am still NED with 2-1/2 yrs. on Tamoxifen.  Still cant believe it.  I am in my sixties and read that Tamoxifen doesn't work as well as Arimidex when you are older.  Arimidex and Tamoxifen work completely differently so I believe that each new hormonal can help you in a new way.

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2013 09:28AM sueco wrote: No more weight loss.  Today is the best I have felt in two weeks.  Stomach feels a little better.  I even feel like shopping!  I am beginning to wonder if maybe my fast weight loss could have been Faslodex leaving my system.  I was on it two years and gained 9 lb.  That is what I have now lost.  I have always been a water and liquid drinker so my fast loss was not due to not drinking enough.  I do find that drinking gingerale helps my stomach.  I will remember to have walnuts and pecans to munch on from now on.  My stomach also is ready for apples and chocolate milk and cinnamon bread.

Posts.Content: sueco wrote: I started Afinitor (chemo pill) two months ago.  First month no loss.  Now 6 lb. loss in 4 days for a total of 9 lbs.  Does weight loss just keep continuing on chemo or level off.  I have no appetite with a sick feeling stomach but force myself to eat three times a day, just smaller amounts.  Tough way to lose pounds but I did have pounds to lose. Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2015 11:00PM sueco wrote: I discussed the Medicare cut back on PET scans with my oncologist.  She said I need not worry.  In fact, I get one every six months (9 years now), and I had one spot she was uncertain of at the last PET so she wants one in 3 months.  I said you mean Medicare will pay for one again this soon.  She explained that yes Medicare is cutting back on PET scans but not if you are in active treatment.  Say someone fears they may have breast cancer or other cancers, and they want a PET scan.  In those cases they may be denied.  My health system here will let you get on line to see blood work right away.  However, with a PET scan I cannot get the results until I see my oncologist.  I usually schedule the scan one or two days prior to my appointment with her.  I also prefer not knowing the results of my scan until I see her as she shows the film to me and explains changes.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2013 03:24PM sueco wrote: 137 is the correct number.  I can't believe that I have ever posted that often!
Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2012 06:35AM sueco wrote: In April 2006 a female oncologist I had visited (had decided to use a different oncologist and called her office to let them know) called me at home and told me the cancer had spread to my bones and I had 2 to 5 years to live.  Believe me I never asked her on the phone.  When I reached the 5-year mark, I sent her a letter and asked how she could have told me such a thing over the phone, how I have worried every day the last five years, and that I was still alive, etc.  Basically told her to never tell another patient how long they had to live unless they asked her.  No doctor can tell how you will react to all the new medicines that are available now.  I hope our responses will help you through this difficult time.
Posts.Title: Expected Life SPAMgirl jocanuck1951

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2012 06:09PM sueco wrote: Sweat pants would work.  You just dont want to wear any pants with metal, and an elastic waist helps.  even walmart has capri pants and slacks that have elastic waists that you could wear again on a daily basis.  The Danskin brand has some real comfy clothing at walmart.
Posts.Title: Scan time and yoga pants myangels nancyh

Posts.Content: sueco wrote: I have had bone mets for seven years.  I was on a different hormone therapy med like every second year when one no longer worked.  Had to start first chemo, Afinitor, in February.  My lungs were a mess from that chemo and had to go off of it.  Was on it 3 months.  My oncologist suggested a chemo break.  It has been 3 months since I have had any medications.  Had a CAT scan last week to check on just two bone mets as I could not have another PET scan so soon.  The CAT scan showed no growth so I can continue as is and have a PET scan in November.  Just does not feel right taking no medication, but it is heaven to not have a sick stomach anymore from Afinitor. Sue Dx 4/15/2006, Stage IV, mets, ER+ Hormonal Therapy 5/15/2006 Arimidex (anastrozole) Hormonal Therapy 8/18/2008 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Hormonal Therapy 10/20/2010 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy 2/14/2013 Afinitor (everolimus) Radiation Therapy 1/15/2014 3DCRT: Bone Chemotherapy 2/17/2014 Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy 8/20/2015 Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Chemo break anyone? - only bone mets sueco TXGigi

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2013 04:35PM sueco wrote: Do you just have bone mets?  I value the last seven years when I was just taking anti-hormones - Arimidex for 2 years, Tamoxifen for 2 years, and Faslodex 2.5 years.  They kept my numerous bone mets sleeping for 7 years.  I have bone mets in vertebra and hips.  I some days felt like an old woman on these meds with stiff joints and aching muscles.  I am now on A/A because I had no new anti-hormone to use.  Having never been on a chemo, I find this has been hard on my body.  Only one mouth sore, first month was easy, now into third month.  The last two weeks have been difficult with total fatigue, no appetite, lost 9 lbs.  I only wish my stomach would feel like normal, and I could at least feel like eating.  I force myself to eat but only eat small portions.  I have not read of others though commenting on a sick stomach so this med will affect everyone differently.  I never used Femara but it is similar to at least one of the anti-hormones I took.  I never could believe how a tiny pill and Faslodex saved me from chemo for 7 years.  Good luck in your decision.  Sounds like your doctor knows of this new drug for breast cancer.
Posts.Title: Managing side effects of aromasin and afinitor babs1208 sueco

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2012 03:10PM sueco wrote: I have been reading other posts for months and it seemed like few had side effects from Faslodex.  I too feel like a 90 yr old.  I do not have your severe pain but I ache all over.  My main problem is the stiffness of my legs when I walk.  The right knee hurts when I bend it and just does not make it possible to walk normally.  No pain except knee  - just stiffness and achiness.  This all started when I started Faslodex and has gotten worse.  I also have traveling pain - one shoulder, then the other, then my hip.  I know my hip is bursitis.  Maybe you could check with your doctor.  What helps me a lot is just getting out of the house so my mind is not on my fatigue and aching.  Wishing you less pain during this tough time.
Posts.Title: Faslodex, Fatigue & Feeling Like Crap lukejessesmom susan_02143

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2013 10:46PM sueco wrote:
Posts.Title: Can anyone recommend exercise for a girl with bone mets? listee Just_Sue

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2015 03:47AM sueco wrote: I was on Xeloda for around 13 months for bone mets. Six-month scans showed my several mets sleeping again. 13-month scan showed T1, T2 and L5 woke up again. My doctor said that meant I had to start a new chemo. I took almost a 4-month break from all meds/chemo as two years ago I went to MDAnderson for a second opinion and they said go off everything for several months. I started Abraxane in August and see from your history that you had Abraxane in Nov.2011 and then again in March 2014. Why was there this break? I would also wonder about radiation of T1, but is it close to your spinal cord. I asked about radiating L5 as I have had that met for almost 9 years off and on. She showed me the PET scan and it is not close to my spinal cord, so no need for radiation. All my hormone meds seemed to work for around two years. By the way, Xeloda was my first chemo and it was much easier on my body than Abraxane. Had wine every weekend, had more energy, but then others have a hard time on it. Best of luck on the course you decide on.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2013 10:02AM sueco wrote: I only have bone mets for the last 7 years.  I have never had pain during this time except for the aching legs and hips.  I thught the one hip was bursitsis which did show up on one PET scan.  The aching did travel from one part of the leg to the next and one hip to another.  I remember trying to move positions in bed but little helped.  However, I either slept at some point or they did not ache straight throught.  I started Afinitor/Aromosin in January when the bone mets woke up again.
Posts.Title: Faslodex and aching legs/hip sueco cheryl1946

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2015 09:16AM sueco wrote: Winningsofar: I agree with you. After my fourth Abraxane IV, I will see the PET scan results. If it shows NED, I also feel I want a normal life and will say no more chemo for awhile as the neuropathy and total fatigue are things I do not want to experience again for awhile. I think back to when I went to MDAnderson two years ago. At that time I had around six active bone mets. They still told my doctor to not start chemo for several months. My next PET scan still showed the six active bone mets but no spread to an organ. One met did have to be radiated at that time as it had grown a bit and was pressing against a nerve. I then started the pill chemo, Xeloda, and after six months I was NED. I stayed on it as I had so few side effects. My next PET scan showed three of the previous six mets woke up. I was told I needed to start a new chemo. I said not for 3 months as I wanted to travel and enjoy some time off from chemo as MDA approved it before. TexasRose said she will always be on chemo, and I recall others saying this. I wonder how our bodies and immune system can handle this for years. I am also so confused as you always read of well known people who have cancer in an organ, have chemo, recover and never have continuing chemo. Is breast cancer different? I believe doctors feel they must keep you on some medication/chemo if you have bone mets. If the cancer spreads to an organ they fear they will have some liability issues. I also know each of us is different so each doctor has to treat each patient the way they feel is the most beneficial...
Posts.Title: NED is gone WinningSoFar WinningSoFar

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2015 12:35AM sueco wrote: RonnieKay: I am wondering what are biologics? Winning: I think this is a smart move. No hair loss either. Lotion your feet a lot as Xeloda affects them.
Posts.Title: NED is gone WinningSoFar WinningSoFar

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2015 10:19AM sueco wrote: I used Udderly Smooth as that is what came with the Xeloda package. I bought thicker, greasy stiff I may have used off and on. I found very good prices for this stuff on Amazon in large containers vs. a small tube. I did buy cotton gloves but wore them like once. My hands were not bad. Cracks on heels bothered me the most, and I don't know what I would have done without New Skin liquid bandage. I was taking Xeloda during cold months so it was not like I was running around bare foot.
Posts.Title: NED is gone WinningSoFar WinningSoFar

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 10:43AM sueco wrote: I was diagnosed in April 2006.  I was ready for chemo until a PET scan showed 4 lesions of the bone.  So no chemo but hormone meds.  As I was 65, I started on Arimidex which worked for two years.  Then a PET scan showed 3 of the old lesions lit up again.  Started on Tamoxifen which is still keeping me NED.  As an earlier responder said, hormone meds are easier than chemo and I have had a good 3-1/2 years.  Two oncologists agreed with no chemo if the cancer is being fed by estrogen.  Best wishes for your mother.
Posts.Title: No chemo therapy for stage IV? ks123 kelly1215

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2008 06:30AM sueco wrote: My oncologist's office gave me a brochure that Zometa out out called "How Zometa Helps Defend Your Independence."  It mentions taking a multivitamin with 400 IU of vitamin D.  Taking an oral calcium supplement of 500 mg. I have never really looked at this brochure before.  Noticed it has info on how bone mets weaken your bones along with pictures showing how it happens.  Pictures of how Zometa breaks the destructive cycle.  I assume Zometa would provide these to all doctors who use it.
Posts.Title: Bone Mets and vitamins/supplements badboob67 jerseymaria

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2008 09:07AM sueco wrote: I was originally diagnosed with breast cancer and bone mets in May 2006.  I am post menopause and was given Arimidex.  Arimidex completely resolved my bone mets for 2.5 years.  The three bone mets then came back.  I was then given Tamoxifen and had a PET scan three months later, and the bone mets were again resolved.  So I now hope Tamoxifen will work as long.  I will have another PET scan in three months.  An old article I read said taking Arimidex as a first line defense will not affect the Tamoxifen defense if it is taken later as they both work differently.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2015 09:08AM sueco wrote: Winningsofar: Thanks for responding. I do have one biggy question. Were you on just six cycles the second time and NED for 18 months after that? My doctor said 4 cycles and then I am due for a PET scan. I know what you mean by normal. I never went off Xeloda for 13 months but was functioning with a good life but feeling like an old lady at times. I fear if the Abraxane puts my bone mets back to sleep she will say gee you need to stay on this chemo UNTIL it stops working. No way. This is week one from chemo last Thursday and I have such fatigue. If like my first infusion, week two and three were much better and I even had a life outside this house. So I get sick thinking of continuing Abraxane month after month so am wondering if you were able to get off it after six cycles. Did you have a PET scan every six months so your doctor could see if you had any changes? Also, a few PET scans ago the radiologist said I could have a met at T-9 but he was not sure and I should have an MRI of that area. My doctor did not think that was necessary and the next PET scan showed nothing in that area, nor had that area ever lite up before. He said it could be arthritis or something like that. I do recall reading that a PET scan can be very inaccurate.at times.
Posts.Title: NED is gone WinningSoFar WinningSoFar

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2015 06:36AM sueco wrote: I have had a permanent sign ever since diagnosed nine years ago. Oh how it helps at times. I just have a hard time walking any long distance. It truly is an asset to have if you are going to a large event and need to park close. I seldom see all handicap parking spots ever taken like at Target, grocery stores, and I have never had anyone question my ability. DO BE CAREFUL THOUGH and never leave your car unlocked as it will be stolen. Colorado is getting much tougher with rules and verification the past few years. For instance if you park in a handicapped car you must also leave the car and shop. Fines have really jumped for people who abuse these rules which is the way it should be.
Posts.Title: Handicap License Plates or Stickers dlb823 car2tenn

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2013 05:57PM sueco wrote: I am on Medicare and have to pay $80 for a 3-month supply.  I do have a supplemental plan though so honestly do not know if Medicare or the Blue Cross plan are paying the expense of this med.  I sure feel worried if Medicare is backing away from providing new treatment for breast cancer patients.  There is another topic on this web site called I believe Afinitor/Aromosin 2012 where there was a lot of discussion on Medicare and health insurance paying for this drug since it was still in a trial phase when this topic started.  The FDS did approve it very recently though for breast cancer.  Best of luck in your research.
Posts.Title: Starting Afinitor and Aromasin, what to expect? hope10 Rseman

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2015 09:53PM sueco wrote: When I was diagnosed in 2006, the oncologist called me at home and said I had bone mets per the PET scan and told me, without my askihg, that I had 2-5 years to live.  I am now going on 9 years.  There are so many meds out there, and each seemed to help me for two years.  Please remember that.   When one fails the next will help.
Posts.Title: 15 -20% 5 year survival rate..huh? LeeLee38 JeninMichigan

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2012 03:39PM sueco wrote: I was getting Zometa for five years by IV.  I was recently switched to take Xgeva instead.  It is easier on the kidneys but the best part is that it is just a shot in the arm.  Before I had to sit in the chemo room while I received Zometa.  I was disagnosed in April of 2006 so cannot believe it has been six years now.  I started out with Arimidex for two years, Tamoxifen for two years and now am on Faslodex.  Xgeve is fairly new but apparently works on the bones just like Zometa.
Posts.Title: Starting Zometa soon CapeTownJanine Marj2007

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2013 02:56PM sueco wrote: I am on Afinitor after years of anti-hormones.  I have always used semi-permanent which I have assumed was less toxic?  I love Clairol brass free natural instincts that lasts 28 shampoos.  I have brown-gray naturally and as it washes out weekly I just think my hair color looks more natural than having a permanent color like some like.  But it is all in one's preference.
Posts.Title: Coloring Hair during Chemo??? RonnieKay Iwillwinthisbattle

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 04:09PM sueco wrote: Two years ago I was put on Arimidex for bone mets.  I had a PET scan every six months to check for progression.  The mets resolved, but three months ago one previous met again showed up.  My oncologist then had me have a PET scan in three months, and there were two new mets.  She now has me taking Tamoxifen.  So in my case PET scans every six months checked to see how long Arimidex was working.  I also had tumor markers done every three months.  These markers have always been normal for me so I do not know if others can detect change in how well their hormonal meds are working by following these markers every three months.  I am scheduled for another PET scan in three months instead of six.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: tamoxifen treatment only-- how to know its working wendy1356 katie11

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 01:21PM sueco wrote: I am confused by this.  A PET scan will  evidence of mets any longer in my pelvis/spine.  Then two years later they wake up again and then go back to sleep when I am given a new anti-hormone med.  My doctor has never said they will go away completely.  Faslodex is now the last anti-hormone out there for me to try and I fear that it will not last long and then I assume I will need chemo for only bone mets.  My January PET scan showed 3 mets are again sleeping with Faslodex and two are smaller.

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2013 06:32PM sueco wrote: Is your home more active around 4 pm.  I feel awful in the morning, sick stomach, etc.  Retired so I really don't have enough to do.  No grandkids.  With being on Afinitor, I have no energy, don't feel up to shopping much, miss my swimming, etc.  My husband is also retired but he is active and going here and there.  I mentally feel better when by noon I feel guilty with my nightgown still on, no makeup.  Once I get dressed and look better it really makes me feel better.  Now if only my stomach felt better.  I tried to hold off on the prescribed anti-nausea pills because I have enough side effects with Afinitor.  Yesterday I decided to try alka-seltzer and the darn pills helped.
Posts.Title: Feeling awful in the mornings. Any ideas? Latte Latte

Posts.Content: sueco wrote: I have been taking Zometa every three months for five years.  I have bone mets which reappear around every two years so I start a new hormone med.  I am now on my last hormone drug, Faslodex.  I asked about taking Xgeva as it is just a shot.  The nurse told me I need to take this every month.  I am concerned about jaw problems, and one oncologist told me my bones can only take so much of this stuff.  Are any of you on Xgena less frequently than every month? Sue Dx 4/15/2006, Stage IV, mets, ER+ Hormonal Therapy 5/15/2006 Arimidex (anastrozole) Hormonal Therapy 8/18/2008 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Hormonal Therapy 10/20/2010 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy 2/14/2013 Afinitor (everolimus) Radiation Therapy 1/15/2014 3DCRT: Bone Chemotherapy 2/17/2014 Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy 8/20/2015 Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2012 06:14PM sueco wrote: I have never had cyber knife.  I had radiation on T8 I think around 4 years ago.  The doctor told me that I would never get cancer back in that area again, and so far I have not.  I get PET scans every 6 months and am now in my seventh year since diagnosis with bone mets.  I even had a MRI around 5 months ago and no mets have grown in the radiated area.  I do believe though from the two black spots on my chest that show where I had radiation that the area they radiated was below and above T8 - more like T9 and T6?  So I hope this will work for you.  I also am under the impression that this area of my vertebrae can not receive any more radiation?
Posts.Title: Cancer returns to area treated with Cyber Knife Bonniejo67 sueco

Posts.Content: May 23, 2013 11:05AM sueco wrote: I have an appt. on June 10.  Was told to allow 5 days.  I was diagnosed in 2007 with bone mets.  Once my doctor had me use the last hormone med she said she would like me to go to MDA.  However, then Afinitor was approved.  I was on it 3 months starting in Jan.  Had PET scan 3 weeks ago and had to go off of it as it was inflamming my lungs.  I was one of the unfortunate ones who has had nausea every day and lost 19 lb.  I have been off Afinitor 3 weeks today and I still have nausea.  I figured all my dr. had to choose from after my lungs get better is the one other chemo pill (can't remember the name) so I feel this is the time to get a second opinion.  My dr. office got all my records together, MDA contacted me with what they need, etc.  My dr. recommended the female oncologist she would prefer I see as she is very good with communication with my doctor.
Posts.Title: Has anyone gone to MD Anderson for second opinion? LizLemon Andirod

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2014 06:02PM sueco wrote: I am into my fourth (2-week period) of Xeloda.  I am an older woman but so far I have had minimum hand/foot problems.  The bottoms of my feet are red and burn a bit.  I do elevate my legs all the time.  I swim and do water ahi chi classes twice a week.  I did this before Xeloda and do not feel my skin is any worse.  Google "does chlorine damage your skin."  I checked quickly and it seems there is not that much chlorine in a pool but you need to shower and apply lotion after getting out.  I am in love with the Udderly Smooth that came with Xeloda.  It just so quickly absorbs in my skin so I use it around three times a day.  I found good prices on drugstore.com so ordered a few pumps which I love.  Much cheaper than what I paid for two 4-oz. bottles at Walgreens.  I sure hope it works for your mom as it is just so wonderful getting in the water and exercising.  Improves one's mood so easily.
Posts.Title: Xeloda, Hand & Foot Syndrome, Swimming Pools? GoldenGirls hansaim

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2007 07:25AM sueco wrote: I live in northern Colorado, and I have not heard of any support groups for just metastatic individuals.  I belong to a support group in a small town where we have around 15 members attend monthly meeting, and three of us have mets.  We lost two members last year.  Everyone is very supportive, but I myself keep a lot of my fears to myself at these meetings.
Posts.Title: New Mexico or Colorado metsters.. Please help gracem CalGal

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2011 07:06PM sueco wrote: If you are ER positve, I assume you will be given anti-hormone meds?  I am going on 5.5 years.  Arimidex put my mets to sleep for two plus years.  Then Tamoxifen put them back to sleep for almost two years.  I am now taking Faslodex and will know in January if this drug will also work as long.  Originally my doctor gave me 2-5 years.  I changed doctors after she gave me this time line on the phone.  When I went past the 5 years, I sent her a letter and told her how her comments hurt me deeply, how could she tell this to someone on the phone, etc.  No doctor can give you a time line as everyone is so different as I have learned in this forum.  Just stay positve as these tiny white pills really work.
